   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:12.6/33.5/1.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:102/3/0.05, ALT / AST:[**11-25**], Alk Phos / T Bili:107/0.6,
   Amylase / Lipase:90/, Differential-Neuts:75.9 %, Lymph:6.9 %, Mono:7.3
   %, Eos:9.6 %, D-dimer:980 ng/mL, Fibrinogen:760 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:0.6
   mmol/L, Albumin:2.8 g/dL, LDH:199 IU/L, Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.2 mg/dL,
   PO4:3.0 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 58-year-old man with history of
   congenital heart disease and repairs in [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status
   post replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves with mosaic
   bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the
   tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on coumadin and multiple
   GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for continued management of heart
   failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible hypoventilated [**1-5**] CHF exacerbation or oxygen
   narcosis. PE also could present similarly but patient was therapeutic
   on coumadin to OSH. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.
   - consider PA catheter/Right heart cath in am
   - wean vent as tolerated
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TTE results
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - additional fluid bolus will be given as patient appears clinically
   dry
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - hold antibiotics as no evidences of infection but follow up blood
   cultures
   - trend hct as below
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - f/u final CXR
   - f/u sputum Cx and gram stain
   - consult pulmonary in am
   - non-contrast chest CT
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - eventually may proceed to RHC
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diureses
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # CORONARIES: No history of CAD on cath [**12-11**]. Cardiogenic shock
   unlikely [**1-5**] to ischemia.
   - f/u EKG
   - f/u cardiac enzymes
   - d/c ASA
   - continue statin
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # AOCKD: Baseline Cr unknown as last documented Cr here when patient
   was acutely ill. Cr now 1.8.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal
   etiology.
   - trend Cr, avoid nephrotoxins if possible
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI
   .
   CODE: full code (per OSH documentation)-need confirmation
   .
   COMM: Proxy name: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3676**] [**Known lastname **]  Relationship: brother  Phone:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10805**]
   .
   Nutrition: tube feed consult
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2201-10-14**] 12:34 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2201-10-14**] 12:37 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs and replacements of valves, and is currently in the ICU due to acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, and potential pulmonary hypertension. He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and is on anticoagulation therapy. His current condition is complicated by a range of factors, including possible hypovolemia, pulmonary hypertension, and potential right ventricular failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia and potential exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) may lead to further respiratory compromise, requiring closer monitoring and potential interventions such as non-invasive ventilation or invasive mechanical ventilation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to a range of factors, including hypovolemia, septic shock, or cardiogenic shock. Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the underlying cause and develop an appropriate treatment plan.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis may be due to a range of causes, including pulmonary embolism, bronchiectasis, or cancer. Further evaluation, including imaging studies and bronchoscopy, is necessary to determine the underlying cause and develop an appropriate treatment plan.
4. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and potential worsening of right ventricular failure may lead to further cardiac compromise, requiring closer monitoring and potential interventions such as inotropes or vasodilators.
5. Right Ventricular Failure: The patient's potential right ventricular failure may lead to further cardiac compromise, requiring closer monitoring and potential interventions such as inotropes or vasodilators.
6. Infective Endocarditis: The patient's history of valve repairs and replacements and his current condition may increase his risk of infective endocarditis, requiring close monitoring and potential antibiotic therapy.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be due to a range of factors, including sepsis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the underlying cause and develop an appropriate treatment plan.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to a range of factors, including bleeding, chronic disease, or nutritional deficiencies. Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the underlying cause and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address his complex medical condition and potential complications.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 58-year-old man with history of
   congenital heart disease and repairs in [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status
   post replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves with mosaic
   bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the
   tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on coumadin and multiple
   GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for continued management of heart
   failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible hypoventilated [**1-5**] CHF exacerbation or oxygen
   narcosis. PE also could present similarly but patient was therapeutic
   on coumadin to OSH. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.
   - consider PA catheter/Right heart cath in am
   - wean vent as tolerated
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TTE results
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - additional fluid bolus will be given as patient appears clinically
   dry
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - hold antibiotics as no evidences of infection but follow up blood
   cultures
   - trend hct as below
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - f/u final CXR
   - f/u sputum Cx and gram stain
   - consult pulmonary in am
   - non-contrast chest CT
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - eventually may proceed to RHC
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diureses
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # CORONARIES: No history of CAD on cath [**12-11**]. Cardiogenic shock
   unlikely [**1-5**] to ischemia.
   - f/u EKG
   - f/u cardiac enzymes
   - d/c ASA
   - continue statin
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # AOCKD: Baseline Cr unknown as last documented Cr here when patient
   was acutely ill. Cr now 1.8.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal
   etiology.
   - trend Cr, avoid nephrotoxins if possible
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, repairs, and subsequent valve replacements. He is currently in the ICU for management of heart failure, respiratory failure, and hemoptysis. His current condition is characterized by:

* Hypertensive hypoxia with a PCO2 in the 60s and bicarbonate in the 40s
* Unclear etiology of hypotension, with possible causes including hypovolemia, overdiuresis, or hemotysis
* Grossly bloody material from the ET tube upon admission, with a negative NG lavage and preliminary CXR unchanged
* History of pulmonary hypertension and borderline RV failure, with worsening RV function and pulmonary hypertension
* Thrombocytopenia, anemia, and eosinophilia, with possible causes including medication reaction or infection

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline RV failure increases the risk of further cardiac compromise, including worsening RV failure, cardiac tamponade, or cardiogenic shock.
3. Bleeding complications: The patient's grossly bloody material from the ET tube and history of hemoptysis increase the risk of further bleeding, including gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial bleeding.
4. Infection: The patient's history of chronic AFib, antibiotic use, and presence of a central line increase the risk of infection, including catheter-related bloodstream infection or pneumonia.
5. Renal failure: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and current oliguria increase the risk of acute kidney injury or worsening renal function.
6. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's current electrolyte imbalances, including hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or other complications.
7. Thrombotic complications: The patient's history of thrombocytopenia and current use of anticoagulation therapy increase the risk of thrombotic complications, including deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's current tube feeding and history of anemia increase the risk of malnutrition, which may worsen his overall condition.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The plan includes:

* Weaning of ventilator support and oxygen therapy
* Management of hypotension with fluid boluses and vasopressors
* Antibiotic stewardship and monitoring for signs of infection
* Monitoring of electrolyte imbalances and acid-base status
* Management of bleeding complications with transfusions and surgical intervention as needed
* Cardiothoracic surgery consultation for valve integrity and possible repair or replacement
* Consideration of PA catheter/Right heart catheter placement for further hemodynamic evaluation
* Monitoring of renal function and electrolyte imbalances
* Nutrition consult for tube feeding and repletion of electrolytes
* Pain management with fentanyl and bowel regimen with senna and colace
* Stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI
* Full code status and communication with the patient's brother, who is the proxy decision-maker.

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs and valve replacements. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, and suspected pulmonary hypertension. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 96 beats per minute, blood pressure of 111/56 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. He is receiving dopamine and norepinephrine infusions to support his blood pressure.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pulmonary Hypertension:** The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and worsening right ventricular failure make it likely that his pulmonary hypertension is worsening, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
2. **Right Ventricular Failure:** The patient's echocardiogram showed elevated pulmonary artery pressure, indicating worsening right ventricular failure. This could lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock.
3. **Hemoptysis:** The patient's hemoptysis could be due to pulmonary hypertension, pulmonary embolism, or cancer. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and potential complications.
4. **Infective Endocarditis:** The patient's history of valve replacements and worsening right ventricular failure make it possible that he has developed infective endocarditis, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
5. **Renal Failure:** The patient's creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL, indicating potential renal impairment. Further monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat renal failure.
6. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia could be due to bleeding, malnutrition, or chronic disease. Further evaluation and management are necessary to address this complication.
7. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's thrombocytopenia could be due to bleeding, sepsis, or medication. Further evaluation and management are necessary to address this complication.
8. **Eosinophilia:** The patient's eosinophilia could be due to a drug reaction or allergic response. Further evaluation and management are necessary to address this complication.
9. **Hypovolemia:** The patient's hypovolemia could lead to further complications, such as hypotension, organ failure, and decreased cardiac output.
10. **Cardiac Arrest:** The patient's history of cardiac disease and current condition make it possible that he could experience cardiac arrest, which would require immediate attention and treatment.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and cardiac function.
2. Consider placing a pulmonary artery catheter to further evaluate the patient's cardiac function and pulmonary hypertension.
3. Wean the patient off dopamine and norepinephrine infusions as tolerated.
4. Consider repeat echocardiogram to further evaluate the patient's cardiac function and valve integrity.
5. Hold diuresis and anticoagulation therapy until further evaluation and management are complete.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and manage them as necessary.
7. Consider consultation with cardiothoracic surgery to further evaluate the patient's cardiac condition and potential for valve repair or replacement.
8. Monitor the patient's hemoptysis and consider further evaluation and management to determine the cause and potential complications.

   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .

   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible CHF exac, pulm HTN, MRSA PNA could have all
   contributed.  No report of aspiration. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is possible, compression of mainstem
   bronchous.

 possible NO later.

   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No

   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries, including valve replacements and a ventricular septal defect (VSD) closure. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and is anticoagulated. His current medications include vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia, dopamine and levophed for hypotension, and fentanyl for pain management.

The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a baseline hypercarbia and acute hypercarbic respiratory failure. His oxygen saturation is 97%, but his partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is elevated. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also unstable, with hypotension and a cardiac output of 3.5 L/min. His cardiac index is 2.5 L/min/m2, and his pulmonary artery pressure is 64-70 mmHg. He has a VSD with bidirectional flow, and his right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with moderate global free wall hypokinesis.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.7 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 181 x 10^9/L. His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a sodium level of 142 mmol/L, a potassium level of 4.1 mmol/L, and a chloride level of 95 mmol/L. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 20 mg/dL, and his creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show a small pleural effusion with bibasal atelectasis, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure. His chest computed tomography (CT) scan also shows a spiculated nodule in the left upper lobe, which may be a primary pulmonary hypertension.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may develop further respiratory failure if his PaCO2 levels continue to rise.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac output is low, and his pulmonary artery pressure is elevated, which may lead to further cardiovascular instability.
3. Infection: The patient has a history of MRSA pneumonia, and he may develop further infections if his immune system is compromised.
4. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis may be a sign of a bleeding disorder or a pulmonary embolism.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be a sign of chronic blood loss or a bleeding disorder.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may be a sign of excessive fluid administration or a bleeding disorder.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be a sign of an allergic reaction or a parasitic infection.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be a sign of a bleeding disorder or a side effect of his medications.
9. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension may be a sign of a chronic lung disease or a pulmonary embolism.
10. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

**Medical History:**

* The patient has a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve.
* He has chronic heart failure, diabetes, and chronic atrial fibrillation on coumadin.
* He has a history of pulmonary hypertension and has been on oxygen therapy at home.

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is currently in the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely due to hypoventilation or oxygen narcosis.
* He has severe pulmonary hypertension and moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation.
* He has a muscular ventricular septal defect with bidirectional flow and right ventricular cavity enlargement with free wall hypokinesis.
* He has a history of hemoptysis, which is currently being investigated.

**Laboratory Results:**

* Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 8.6, Hct 33.0, Platelet count 162
* Blood Chemistry: Sodium 142, Potassium 4.1, Creatinine 1.8, Glucose 126
* Troponin-T: 0.05
* D-dimer: 980 ng/mL
* Fibrinogen: 760 mg/dL
* Lactic Acid: 0.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* LDH: 199 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL
* PO4: 1.8 mg/dL

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Pulmonary hypertension may worsen due to worsening VSD or mitral regurgitation.
* Right ventricular failure may worsen due to pulmonary hypertension.
* Infection, such as pneumonia or sepsis, may be present and contributing to the patient's condition.
* Bleeding or hemorrhage may occur due to thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy.
* Kidney injury or failure may occur due to hypovolemia, nephrotoxins, or pre-renal azotemia.
* Hypoxia or respiratory failure may worsen due to pulmonary hypertension or respiratory acidosis.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider inhaled nitric oxide therapy if necessary.
* Wean dopamine and levophed as tolerated and consider placement of a PA catheter or right heart catheter.
* Monitor the patient's electrolytes, particularly sodium and potassium, and correct any abnormalities.
* Trend the patient's creatinine and adjust diuretic therapy as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and bleeding risk.
* Consider consultation with cardiothoracic surgery regarding valve integrity and potential surgical interventions.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and consider additional testing to rule out ischemic heart disease.

   by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is
   10-20mmHg. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and
   regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%). There is a
   1cm mid-muscular ventricular septal defect (VSD) with bidirectional
   flow. The right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with moderate
   global free wall hypokinesis. The aortic root is moderately dilated at
   the sinus level. The ascending aorta is moderately dilated. The aortic
   valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not
   present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. A bioprosthetic mitral
   valve prosthesis is present. The mitral prosthesis appears well seated,
   with normal leaflet motion and transvalvular gradients. No mitral
   regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of
   mitral regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.] A tricuspid
   valve annuloplasty ring is present with normal gradient. Moderate to
   severe [3+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is severe pulmonary
   artery systolic hypertension. A well-seated pulmonic valve prosthesis
   is present. The gradient is high normal. No pulmonary regurgitation is
   seen. There is no pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Muscular ventricular septal defect with bidirectional flow.
   Right ventricular cavity enlargement with free wall hypokinesis. Severe
   pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Moderate to severe tricuspid
   regurgitation. Slightly increased pulmonic bioprosthetic gradient.
   Normal functioning mitral bioprosthesis.
   CT CHEST:
   IMPRESSION:
   1. No evidence for diffuse systemic lung disease such as interstitial
   lung disease. No fibrosis. No significant pulmonary edema.
   2. Small pleural effusions with relatively out of proportion bibasal
   atelectasis. This atelectasis could certainly compromise the limited
   reserve of this patient. Pneumonia may also coexist in this atelectatic
   lung.
   3. Right pulmonary artery dilatation compresses mainstem bronchi
   particulary onthe right which may also contribute to the limtied
   reserve.
   4. Pattern of ground glass nodulrity can be seen in primary pulmonary
   hypertension.
   5. Spiculated nodule in the left upper lobe. Recommend followup chest
   CT in three months.
   Assessment and Plan
   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible hypoventilated [**1-5**] CHF exacerbation or oxygen
   narcosis. PE also could present similarly but patient was therapeutic
   on coumadin to OSH. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is possible, compression of mainstem
   bronchous.
   - Pulm will bronch in AM
 possible NO later.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TSH, vanc lvl (target 3 wks of vanc treatment).
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - additional fluid bolus will be given as patient appears clinically
   dry (i/o even)
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - hold antibiotics as no evidences of infection but follow up blood
   cultures
   - trend hct as below
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - f/u CXR am
   - f/u sputum Cx and gram stain
   - pulmonary bronch in am
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - eventually may proceed to RHC
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diureses
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # CORONARIES: No history of CAD on cath [**12-11**]. Cardiogenic shock
   unlikely [**1-5**] to ischemia.
   - f/u EKG
   - f/u cardiac enzymes
   - d/c ASA
   - continue statin
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # AOCKD: Baseline Cr unknown as last documented Cr here when patient
   was acutely ill. Cr now 1.8.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal
   etiology.
   - trend Cr, avoid nephrotoxins if possible
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of a ventricular septal defect (VSD) and patent foramen ovale (PFO), and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He is currently admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a baseline hypercarbia and a recent exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is on oxygen therapy at home for presumed pulmonary hypertension. The etiology of the initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but it may be related to a CHF exacerbation, oxygen narcosis, or PE.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also concerning, with a history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline RV failure. His pulmonary hypertension is likely worsened by his VSD or mitral regurgitation. He is on coumadin for anticoagulation, which may have contributed to his recent bleeding.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and eosinophilia, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or recent medications. His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia.

The patient's medical history includes diabetes, depression, and anxiety, which may impact his overall health and treatment.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia and recent exacerbation of COPD make him at high risk for respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline RV failure increases his risk of cardiac arrest.
3. Bleeding: The patient's recent bleeding and thrombocytopenia make him at high risk for further bleeding complications.
4. Infection: The patient's recent antibiotics and history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease make him at high risk for infection.
5. Worsening of underlying medical conditions: The patient's history of diabetes, depression, and anxiety make him at high risk for worsening of these conditions.

To address these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored in the ICU, with frequent assessments of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status. He should also receive targeted therapy for his underlying medical conditions, including antibiotics for his suspected MRSA pneumonia, and close monitoring of his electrolyte levels and bleeding risk.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including replacement of the pulmonic and mitral valves with bioprostheses. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin. He has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and is receiving vancomycin.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbic respiratory failure is likely to worsen due to his underlying pulmonary hypertension and possible tricuspid regurgitation.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension may be due to cardiogenic shock, hypovolemia, or a combination of both. His cardiac function is compromised, and he may require further interventions to stabilize his hemodynamics.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis may be due to pneumonia, bronchiectasis, pulmonary artery malformation, or cancer. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and plan appropriate management.
4. Infective endocarditis: The patient's history of congenital heart disease and replacement of valves with bioprostheses increases his risk of developing infective endocarditis. Further evaluation is needed to rule out this possibility.
5. Worsening renal function: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen due to his underlying cardiac and respiratory dysfunction.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hyponatremia and hyperkalemia may require further management to prevent complications.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be due to his underlying medical conditions or the use of certain medications. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and plan appropriate management.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to his underlying medical conditions or bleeding. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and plan appropriate management.

Based on the patient's condition, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue to optimize his respiratory function by adjusting his ventilator settings and providing bronchodilators as needed.
2. Monitor his cardiovascular stability closely and adjust his medication regimen as needed to maintain optimal hemodynamics.
3. Continue to evaluate and manage his hemoptysis, considering further imaging studies and bronchoscopy as needed.
4. Monitor his renal function closely and adjust his fluid management and medication regimen as needed to prevent further worsening of his kidney function.
5. Monitor his electrolyte balance closely and adjust his medication regimen as needed to prevent complications.
6. Continue to evaluate and manage his thrombocytopenia, considering further laboratory testing and consultation with hematology as needed.
7. Continue to evaluate and manage his anemia, considering further laboratory testing and consultation with hematology as needed.
8. Consider further consultation with cardiology and cardiothoracic surgery to evaluate the patient's valve function and consider potential interventions to improve his cardiac function.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He is currently admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, and suspected pulmonary hypertension.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia and oxygen dependence may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of congenital heart disease, pulmonary hypertension, and possible valve deterioration may lead to cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock, heart failure, or arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's history of MRSA pneumonia and the presence of a central line may increase the risk of central line-associated bloodstream infections.
4. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension and possible hypovolemia may lead to further hemodynamic instability, including cardiac arrest.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's hemoptysis and possible coagulopathy may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and possible pre-renal azotemia may worsen, leading to renal failure.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia and possible bleeding may worsen, leading to further anemia and potential complications.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
9. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may indicate an allergic reaction or hypersensitivity reaction, which may worsen or lead to other complications.
10. Hypercarbic acidosis: The patient's hypercarbic acidosis may worsen, leading to further respiratory and metabolic complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Bronchoscopy to assess the patient's airway and possible causes of hemoptysis.
2. Pulmonary artery catheterization to assess the patient's cardiac function and hemodynamics.
3. Continuous monitoring of the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
4. Administration of vasopressors and inotropes to support the patient's blood pressure and cardiac function.
5. Management of the patient's hypercarbic acidosis with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
6. Monitoring of the patient's electrolyte levels and acid-base status.
7. Administration of antibiotics to treat possible infections.
8. Monitoring of the patient's platelet count and coagulation status.
9. Management of the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and iron supplementation.
10. Monitoring of the patient's renal function and possible need for dialysis.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his clinical outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a complex medical history, including congenital heart disease, multiple valve repairs, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis.

The patient's current medical condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He has severe restrictive ventilatory impairment and chronic respiratory acidosis, which is likely exacerbated by his underlying pulmonary hypertension and tricuspid regurgitation. He requires mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 27 cmH2O and a plateau pressure (Pplat) of 23 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular: He has a history of pulmonary hypertension, which is likely worsening his right ventricular function. He also has a muscular ventricular septal defect with bidirectional flow, which may be contributing to his hypotension.
* Hemodynamic: His central venous pressure (CVP) is 16 mmHg, which may not accurately reflect his volume status due to his tricuspid regurgitation. His mean arterial pressure (MAP) is 60 mmHg, and he requires dopamine and levophed to maintain adequate blood pressure.
* Renal: His creatinine (Cr) is 1.8 mg/dL, and his urine output is 2.5 L in the past 24 hours. He has a history of anemia, and his hemoglobin (Hb) is 10.2 g/dL.
* Coagulation: He has thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 162 x 10^9/L and is at risk for bleeding.
* Infection: He has a positive sputum culture for MRSA and is receiving vancomycin. He also has a history of pneumonia and bronchiectasis.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a history of chronic diarrhea and is receiving tube feeds.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's severe restrictive ventilatory impairment and chronic respiratory acidosis make him at high risk for respiratory failure.
* Cardiac failure: His worsening right ventricular function and pulmonary hypertension may lead to cardiac failure.
* Bleeding: His thrombocytopenia and history of bleeding make him at risk for bleeding complications.
* Infection: His positive sputum culture and history of pneumonia and bronchiectasis make him at risk for developing a secondary infection.
* Renal failure: His elevated creatinine and history of anemia make him at risk for developing renal failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: His history of chronic diarrhea and tube feeds make him at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on this information, the patient's treatment plan should focus on optimizing his respiratory and cardiovascular status, managing his bleeding risk, and preventing infection. Further evaluation and management of his underlying conditions, including his pulmonary hypertension and tricuspid regurgitation, are also necessary.

   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.

   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .

   recs
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # ARF: Cr now improving s/p fluid bolus.  Urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.
   - trend Cr
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts

Based on the provided medical note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, pulmonary hypertension, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. The patient has undergone multiple cardiac surgeries and has a history of valve repairs.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has acute respiratory failure with a PCO2 of 60s and a baseline bicarb of 40s. He is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. The patient's respiratory status is hypercarbic at baseline.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypotension with a blood pressure of 88/38 mmHg. His cardiac output is compromised, and he is receiving inotropic support with dopamine and norepinephrine. His central venous pressure (CVP) is 7 mmHg, which may not accurately reflect his volume status due to tricuspid regurgitation.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's hemodynamic status is compromised, with a cardiac index of 1.4 L/min/m2 and a pulmonary artery pressure of 60 mmHg. He is receiving vasopressor support to maintain his mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine of 1.4 mg/dL. His urine output is 1.975 mL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 35 mg/dL.
* Electrolytes: The patient has hyponatremia with a sodium level of 135 mEq/L. His potassium level is 4.1 mEq/L, and his calcium level is 8.1 mg/dL.
* Coagulation: The patient has thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 191 x 10^9/L. His international normalized ratio (INR) is 1.2, and his partial thromboplastin time (PTT) is 34.6 seconds.
* Infectious: The patient has methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia, which was confirmed by sputum culture. He is receiving vancomycin and cefepime for treatment.
* Other: The patient has an eosinophilic rash, which is likely related to a drug eruption. He is receiving antihistamines and corticosteroids for treatment.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is hypercarbic at baseline, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac output is compromised, and he is at risk for further deterioration due to his underlying pulmonary hypertension and tricuspid regurgitation.
3. Renal failure: The patient has AKI, and his creatinine level is increasing. He is at risk for further deterioration and may require renal replacement therapy.
4. Bleeding: The patient has thrombocytopenia and is at risk for bleeding. He is receiving anticoagulation therapy, which may increase his risk of bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient has MRSA pneumonia, and he is at risk for further infection due to his underlying pulmonary hypertension and immunosuppression.
6. Eosinophilic reaction: The patient has an eosinophilic rash, which may be related to a drug eruption. He is at risk for further deterioration and may require treatment with corticosteroids and antihistamines.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which may be related to his underlying disease or treatment. He is at risk for bleeding and may require platelet transfusions.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O to manage the patient's respiratory status.
2. Continue inotropic support with dopamine and norepinephrine to maintain the patient's MAP above 60 mmHg.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and urine output closely, and consider initiating renal replacement therapy if his creatinine level continues to increase.
4. Monitor the patient's platelet count and bleeding risk, and consider transfusing platelets if his platelet count falls below 10 x 10^9/L.
5. Continue antibiotic therapy for MRSA pneumonia, and monitor the patient's response to treatment.
6. Monitor the patient's eosinophilic rash and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.
7. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiothoracic surgery service for further evaluation and management of his cardiac condition.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and potential complications. Close monitoring and careful management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and optimize his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-inch tall male with a weight of 90.3 kg, admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, heart failure, and altered mental status. The patient has a history of pulmonary hypertension, and the CT scan shows bibasal atelectasis, small pleural effusions, and a spiculated nodule in the left upper lobe.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.8°C (100.1°F)
* Heart rate: 75 bpm
* Blood pressure: 88/38 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 99%
* Central venous pressure: 7 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.5 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 207 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 35 mmol/L
* Glucose: 143 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: sodium 135 mmol/L, potassium 4.1 mmol/L, chloride 97 mmol/L, and magnesium 2.0 mmol/L

The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to the presence of atelectasis, pneumonia, and pulmonary hypertension.
2. Heart failure: The patient's heart failure may worsen due to the presence of systolic and diastolic dysfunction, which may lead to increased fluid accumulation and decreased cardiac output.
3. Sepsis: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may be related to sepsis, which may be triggered by the presence of pneumonia or other infections.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output may indicate acute kidney injury, which may be related to the patient's heart failure, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which may be triggered by the patient's heart failure, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
6. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's presence of pulmonary hypertension and small pleural effusions may increase the risk of pulmonary embolism, which may be triggered by the patient's immobility and underlying conditions.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and renal function to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

   PO4:3.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # ARF: Cr now improving s/p fluid bolus.  Urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.
   - trend Cr
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI
   .
   CODE: full code (per OSH documentation)-need confirmation
   .
   COMM: Proxy name: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3676**] [**Known lastname **]  Relationship: brother  Phone:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10805**]
   .
   Nutrition: tube feed consult
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .

   - follow QID FS with HISS

   .

   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs of the pulmonic and mitral valves, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He has chronic atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, and diabetes. He was transferred to the ICU from the operating room with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and hemoptysis. He has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime. He also has pulmonary hypertension, which is likely worsening his right ventricular failure.

Potential medical complications:

1. Worsening right ventricular failure: The patient's pulmonary hypertension and borderline RV failure may worsen, leading to further hemodynamic instability.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has MRSA pneumonia, which may worsen and lead to sepsis or respiratory failure.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis may worsen, leading to bleeding and respiratory compromise.
4. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further bleeding and respiratory compromise.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding and respiratory compromise.
8. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may worsen, leading to allergic reactions or anaphylaxis.
9. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen, leading to further dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
10. ARF: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further kidney dysfunction or failure.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's hemodynamics closely and adjust therapy accordingly.
2. Continue treatment for MRSA pneumonia with vancomycin and cefepime.
3. Monitor the patient's oxygenation and ventilator settings to prevent further respiratory compromise.
4. Consider diuresis and fluid management to prevent further hypotension and hyponatremia.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding and adjust therapy accordingly to prevent further bleeding.
6. Consider transfusions to correct anemia and thrombocytopenia.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust therapy accordingly to prevent further electrolyte imbalance.
8. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent further bleeding.
9. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy accordingly to prevent further kidney dysfunction or failure.
10. Consider consulting a cardiologist and cardiothoracic surgeon to further evaluate and manage the patient's cardiac condition.

   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.
   - Bronch c/w PNA
       - sent for cultures and on cefepime now, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.
   Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o even)
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs
   - f/u vanc level
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # ARF: Cr now improving s/p fluid bolus.  Urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.
   - trend Cr
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos

   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease, repairs, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia, and is being treated with antibiotics and respiratory support. He also has hypotension, possibly due to hypovolemia, cardiac failure, or septic shock. He has a history of pulmonary hypertension and is at risk for right ventricular failure. He has a recent history of hemoptysis and is being treated for MRSA pneumonia. He has thrombocytopenia, eosinophilia, and anemia, and is being treated for these conditions.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypercarbic respiratory failure may progress to chronic respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure puts him at risk for worsening cardiac function.
3. Sepsis: The patient's MRSA pneumonia and hypotension increase his risk of developing sepsis.
4. Bleeding: The patient's history of hemoptysis and thrombocytopenia increase his risk of bleeding complications.
5. Kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's history of hyponatremia and hypokalemia increase his risk of electrolyte imbalances.
7. Infection: The patient's history of MRSA pneumonia and eosinophilia increase his risk of developing further infections.
8. Thrombosis: The patient's history of thrombocytopenia and pulmonary hypertension increase his risk of developing thrombotic complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue respiratory support and monitor for signs of worsening respiratory failure.
2. Monitor cardiac function and consider echocardiogram to assess right ventricular function.
3. Continue antibiotic treatment for MRSA pneumonia and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Monitor bleeding risk and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
5. Monitor kidney function and consider dialysis if necessary.
6. Monitor electrolyte levels and consider IV fluids if necessary.
7. Monitor for signs of infection and consider further testing if necessary.
8. Consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent thrombotic complications.

   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most likely PNA in the setting of COPD.  No report of
   aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to
   baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.  NOTE: MRSA pna is
   possible, compression of mainstem bronchous.

   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerate, goal sat lower, turn down peep and FiO2.

   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus

   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
